INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Organisation pour la Mise en Valeur du Fleuve Senegal (OMVS ) was created in 1972 by Mali, Mauritania, and Senegal to promote the economic development of the Senegal River Basin for purposes of irrigation, power supply and navigation. A member of the initially called Organisation des Etats Riverains du Senegal (OERS), Guinea has now a status of observer in OMVS. The Senegal River, 1,800 km long, is one of the largest rivers in Africa. It begins in Guinea, flows north across the western part of Mali, then turns north east, marking the border between Senegal and Mauritania until it reaches the Atlantic Ocean at St. Louis (Map 28332). The total surface of the Senegal River Basin is about 290,000 km and supports a population of about two million people, or about 10% of the population of the three countries. It consists of three main regions: the upper basin, the valley and the delta. It is the heavy rainfall in the upper basin that provides almost the whole of the flow of the Senegal River which brings water and life downstream to a vast stretch of land in desert and dry regions of Mauritania and Senegal. These rains fall from April to October, causing an annual flood in the river for about two months every year. Agriculture in the valley has traditionally depended on the annual flood. The flood also allows the raising of livestock, the recharging of shallow acquifers that are tapped for village water supply, the regeneration of vegetation cover and the reproduction of fish. In the past few decades, however, all these activities were severely hampered due to drought, and malnutrition forced people to migrate out of the valley. 1.2 It is partly in response to the severe drought and famine of the early 1970s that creation of OMVS was accelerated. The original plans for OMVS called for the development of controlled irrigation to permit double cropping of about 375.000 ha. The integrated development plan also envisaged (a) barge traffic from Saint-Louis to Kayes; and (b) power supply to centers that could be economically and technically served from hydropower sites. In 1981, with financing of about US$620 million from 12 donors, construction began on two dams - one at Diama, on the river delta, to prevent intrusion of salt water into the lower valley and a second at Manantali in western Mali, for water storage, river flow regulation and power generation. Both dams have been in operation since 1988. The barrier dam at Diama has made irrigated agriculture possible throughout the year and allowed the supply of water for populations and cattle upstream from Diama and for the city of Dakar. Storage of the annual flood by the Manantali dam has allowed OMVS to maintain the Diama reservoir at full and stable level, and to raise levels of two lakes (Guiers and Rkiz) considerably reducing costs for pumped irrigation systems around these water bodies. Because of these improvements, irrigated agriculture has become a major economic force in the valley. As of 1996, about 100,000 ha of controlled irrigation have been developed. In addition, OMVS has tried to maintain an artificial flood for the population dependent on flood recession agriculture with a target area of 50,000 ha, that can be cultivated in all but the driest years. 1.3 While the navigation components of the integrated development plan for the valley show little prospect of being justified in the medium-term and may have to be deferred, there is significant demand for power in the capital cities of Bamako, Nouakchott, and Dakar and in the Senegal Valley itself, to justify the development of power generation facilities at Manantali. The power facilities would help minimizing the long-term cost of electricity supply to the three countries and improve the financial situation of local utilities. Without the power component, no significant revenues would be generated from the dams, revenues that could be used to reduce outstanding debt incurred in constructing the two dams. Development of the power facilities fits well with the country assistance strategies of the three countries which seek to lower domestic factor costs, including energy costs, the development of agriculture and infrastructure and the promotion of private sectors. The power project will also help mitigate the environmental and health problems that were caused by the building of the two dams.
 2 2. THE ENERGY SECTORS 2 2.1 Together, Mali, Mauritania and Senegal have a large surface area of about 2.5 million km , but the countries have limited natural resources. As a result, the combined population of 20 million are among the world's poorest. The economies are largely dependent on agriculture and fisheries which are the primary source of income for most their population and account for the largest share of product exports. Energy consumption in Mali, Mauritania and Senegal is dominated by fuelwood which accounts for between 60% and 90% of the energy used. All three countries rely almost entirely on imports to meet all their petroleum needs, with the exception of limited gas and oil production in Senegal. Power generation is mainly thermal-based, with the exception of small hydroelectric plants in Mali. The Manantali dam, also located in Mali, on the Senegal River is the first major attempt to use the region's domestic resources to meet the demand for commercial energy in the three countries. 2.2 Some of the major issues in the energy sector in Mali are the high cost of energy (petroleum and power), the limited access to power supply (especially in Mali and Mauritania), the unreliability and poor quality of power supply (load shedding in Mali and Senegal), excessive Government involvement in the power sector, the sector's adverse impact on public finances due to poor financial performance of Government-owned utilities and large investment needs and the lack of private investment in the power sector. In the household energy sector, the uncontrolled "mining" of wood has led to deforestation around major cities and to an increase in CO2 emissions. Mali 2 2.3 Background: Of the three countries, Mali is the largest, with an area of 1.24 million km . The population was estimated at 10 million in 1995, with 80% living in rural areas. Its per capita income was estimated at US$250 in 1995. Of the eight main cities in Mali, only Bamako, the capital, with a population of about 800,000 inhabitants, is a major urban center. During the last six years, the Government of Mali has undertaken major economic reforms, with the underlying objective of improving the competitiveness of the economy and laying the foundation for sustained long-term growth needed to help raise the standard of living and alleviate poverty. These reforms have removed bottlenecks to private sector participation, allowing market forces to play a more important role in the determination of economic outcomes. The impact of these reforms, including the change in parity of the CFA Franc in January, 1994, is shown by the improvement in economic performance over the adjustment period. Real GDP grew at a rate of 6% in 1995 compared to 2.4% in 1994. Inflation was contained at about 12.5% compared to 24.8% in 1994. Budgetary revenues increased by 27.5% and export revenues by 27%. 2.4 Energy Resources and Consumption: Mali's domestic energy resources consist of biomass (fuelwood, charcoal, agricultural and agro-industrial residues), hydropower, and solar energy. Presently, only biomass for household energy and hydropower are exploited on a significant scale. The country's hydropower potential, based on the Senegal and Niger river systems, is estimated at about 1,000 MW capable of producing 5,000 GWh in an average year. Of this potential, only about 50 MW (220 GWh)
 3 have been developed so far, at the Selingue and Sotuba plants on the Niger River and the Felou plant on the Senegal river. Mali has no significant known fossil fuels and petroleum product consumption is entirely dependent on imports (about 200,000 tons annually). Final energy consumption is low and was estimated in 1992 at 1.83 million tons of oil equivalent (toe) which corresponds to a consumption of 200 kg of oil equivalent per capita per year. Fuelwood and charcoal represent more than 88% of the consumption. 2.5 Energy Issues and Government Strategy: Major issues in the sector include the high cost of power and petroleum, the limited access to and poor quality of power supply and accelerated deforestation in areas supplying woodfuels to urban centers. To address these issues, the Government of Mali has contracted the management of the power/water utility (EDM) to a private operator for a period of four years, is making efforts to reduce the fragmented responsibility for investment planning and system operation, and is investing in repairs of its hydropower facilities and expansion of thermal power plants. Further private involvement is being contemplated, possibly under a concession contract or through privatization of EDM, and/or independent power producers schemes (IPPs) to increase productivity of the utility. In the petroleum sector, the Government has: (a) negotiated with the refineries in Senegal (SAR) and C6te d'Ivoire (SIR) a lower price for their petroleum products, which has saved the economy over US$10 million a year; (b) fully liberalized the procurement and distribution of petroleum products; and (c) adopted a simplified system of tax collection at customs, incorporating into a single tax all of the previous many taxation components. These measures have resulted in increased competition and lower prices for petroleum products. Actions are being taken by the Government to tackle the problem in the household energy sector, both on the supply and demand sides, including the transfer of responsibility for the control and management of the natural forests from the State to the local rural communities, the revision of the woodfuel tax system, and the promotion of inter- fuel substitution and improved cooking stoves. Mauritania 2.6 Background: Mauritania is also a vast country with 1.1 million kM2, but with a population of only about 2 million people. The rate of urbanization is high, however, with over 60% living in towns. The capital city of Nouakchott, established only three decades ago, now has about 730,000 inhabitants, or nearly a third of the country's population. This is partly because of the impact of desertification, which has been complicated by Mauritania's economic management performance which has seen a checkered history. A foreign-led boom of investment and growth in the 1960s was followed by stagnation and economic crisis in the 70s. Concerted efforts to focus on economic reform essentially date from 1985, when the economic adjustment program now underway was launched. Efforts were interrupted in 1989 by social turbulence. Since 1992, however, Mauritania's implementation of structural policies have generally been satisfactory and hopes for a better future for this poorly endowed country rest on mining and fisheries, which if well managed, offer good development potential. Major infrastructure investments in the Senegal Valley have been made or are envisaged, including power, which now offers a much richer potential for agricultural development. Mauritania has also made important strides in human resource development, while the existence of a dynamic private sector offers the potential of significant economic growth. 2.7 Energy Resources and Consumption: Mauritania's known energy resource base is small and essentially consists of a fragile forest cover and potentially wind and solar energy. Energy consumption is relatively low and is estimated at 0.55 million tons of oil equivalent (toe) in 1995. It is entirely dependent on the importation of petroleum products to meet its commercial energy needs. Petroleum products are supplied by a Government-owned refinery with a capacity of one million tons per year,
 4 located in the north of the country at Nouadhibou. The refinery imports crude oil from Algeria as well as refined products at international prices. The annual consumption of petroleum products total some 315,000 tons/year. Household energy needs are met from domestic woodfuel resources, which are rapidly dwindling. It is estimated that the production potential of forest resources in Mauritania is 100,000 tons a year, while consumption is estimated at 500,000 tons or five times the estimated rate of regeneration. Electric power is supplied by isolated systems based on diesel generators. Less than half of the generation capacity is publicly owned and managed by the local utility, SONELEC, and the rest by the refinery and mining industry (SNIM mainly). 2.8 Energy Issues and Government Strategy: The energy sector in Mauritania suffers a number of problems: (a) petroleum imports continue to be a burden on the balance of payments; (b) the infrastructure facilities at both Nouakchott and Nouadhibou are inadequate to handle unloading and storage of petroleum products, increasing costs and, in the case of Nouakchott could lead to a sudden rupture in supplies; (c) until recently the reliability and efficiency of power supply was low; (d) the cost of power generation remains relatively high, particularly for the population in the interior of the country and the Senegal River valley; and (e) the adverse climatic conditions and the growth in the demand for household fuels have put an enormous pressure on the natural vegetation cover and has led to severe depletion in the country's meager forest resources. 2.9 Beginning in 1987, the Government of Mauritania pursued a well designed strategy that sought to (a) attract private oil companies to explore for petroleum in the country; (b) liberalize the procurement and distribution of petroleum products; (c) promote the conservation of woodfuel resources by promoting improved wood and charcoal stoves and interfuel substitution; and (d) allow SONELEC more autonomy to manage and operate the power sector. As a result, several oil companies signed contracts to explore for petroleum off-shore where the prospects were the brightest. Secondly, there was a large increase in the consumption of LPG by households and some experimentation with solar and wind energy, which reduced the pressures on the local remaining woodfuel resources. Thirdly, SONELEC was able to reliably supply power to an increasing number of consumers without being a burden on the public budget. Senegal 2 2.10 Background: Senegal is the smallest of the three countries with an area of 197,000 km . Senegal's GNP of US$608 per capita in 1995 places it among the lower-middle income economies, with a population of 9.2 million growing at a high but declining rate of about 2.7% a year. This is greater than the rate of growth of GDP which was 1.9% from 1985 through 1995. The level of urbanization is 42% and growing, placing it well above the sub-Saharan Africa average of 28%. The country's social indicators are low and stagnant. The adult literacy rate is about 33%; primary school enrollment is at 56%. Modern sector activities are concentrated around the capital city of Dakar which has a population of about 2.5 million and along the coast. Foreign exchange reserves are earned principally from groundnut, phosphate, chemical and fish exports and from tourism. Agriculture accounts for about 20% of GDP but employs 60% of the population. Groundnuts are the most important crop, accounting for 75% of farm cash income. Since the beginning of the 1990s, the economy experienced a serious decline, with a contraction of output in key sectors, including food and fish processing, phosphates and textiles. In an attempt to reverse this economic deterioration the Government adopted a series of adjustment measures in 1993, including cuts in public sector wages. After the devaluation of the currency in 1994, the Government started to implement a medium-term strategy for the development of the private sector. As a result, GDP is estimated to have grown by 4.8% in 1995, with substantial growth in exports of fish, groundnut products, phosphates and tourism. Senegal's privileged geographic location and good
 5 communication infrastructure give it the potential to become a gateway service center in the region and to benefit from its proximity to European markets. 2.11 Energy Resources and Consumption: Senegal has diversified energy resources, but under present conditions their use is associated with either environmental risks (forest-based fuels) or substantial investment outlays for research (hydrocarbons) and mobilization (hydroelectricity, solar and wind power). Energy consumption is dominated by woodfuels, which account for 53% of energy used. Available forest stock information indicates that Senegal could reasonably expect to meet much of its demand for household fuels, provided the forest stock is properly managed. In reality, however, supply of wood to the urban and peri-urban areas is based on geographically concentrated and non-sustainable forest management practices that have led to a gradual loss of forest cover and degradation of the rural environment. The country's hydroelectric potential, based on the Senegal and Gambia rivers is estimated at 1,000 MW which has still to be tapped. Fossil fuels in the form of heavy petroleum was discovered in the 1950s offshore at Dome Flore (100 million tons), but it has yet to be produced. Small amounts of natural gas and light petroleum, however, were discovered and produced onshore near Dakar (Diam Nadio). Between 1987 and 1992, these fields produced 61,000 barrels of crude oil and 31 million cubic meters of natural gas which was used to produce electricity. Additional gas reserves were discovered recently in the same area (amount estimated at 10 billion m3). Most of Senegal's commercial energy needs are met, however, by imported petroleum products which totaled 900,000 tons in 1994 and claimed 16% of export earnings. 2.12 Energy Issues and Government Strategy: Senegal's energy sector is dominated by public sector agencies, the performance of which has been hampered inter alia by a lack of real management autonomy, lack of transparency and competition, and lack of incentives to run efficiently the sector. The cost of petroleum products are high to the economy because the local refinery (Societe Africaine de Raffinage - SAR) has the monopoly to procure all products and refines crude at an uneconomic cost, and has been granted a supplement of US$ 2.30/barrel that has not led to improvements in operational efficiency. Similarly, the local utility, SENELEC, has the monopoly for the production and distribution of electricity, but has been mismanaged, resulting in poor service, deteriorating generating facilities and low level of connections, despite improvements resulting from the action plan implemented as of 1993 (see para. 3.44). In the context of its structural adjustment program, the Government has been taking some important measures in most sectors, except energy. Beginning this year, however, it is determined to implement reforms in the energy sector that are expected to increase the availability of energy, reduce costs and minimize environmental problems. The Government has articulated its policy to deal with household fuels without the loss of forest cover by devolving responsibilities for forest management to local rural communities. In its Letter of Sector Development Policy (February 1997), the Government has also stated its intention of abolishing the monopoly of SAR, liberalizing petroleum procurement and pricing and privatizing the power sector. These measures should lead to lower prices for petroleum products as well as power and better and more efficient service.

The largest is SENELEC (Senegal) with a peak load of 276 MW in 1995 ; Energie du Mali (Mali) has a peak load of 50 MW and SONELEC (Mauritania) is the smallest with a peak load of 31 MW. The financial situation of the power utilities is chronically weak despite relative high electricity tariffs, but is expected to improve with the power supplied by Manantali. MALI (EDM) A. Power Sector Organization 3.2 Established in 1960, Energie du Mali (EDM) is a mixed capital company with the Government holding the majority (97.2%) of the shares and Electricite de France (EdF), the remainder (2.8%). EDM is administrated by a Board with nine members, of which seven are appointed by the Government, one by EdF and one by the staff of EDM. EDM has about 1,300 employees of which 88 are classified as professional staff. Although the total number of staff is high for a utility company of this size, there is still a shortage of suitable qualified staff. EDM has its own training center, the Centre de Perfectionnement du Personnel (CPP), and also sends some staff for training at the Ecole Superieure Interafricaine d'Electricite (ESIE) and the Centre des Metiers de l 'Electricite (CME) in C6te d'Ivoire. 3.3 Sector regulation, policy and coordination are ensured by the Ministry of Mines, Energy and Hydraulics (MMEH). The Ministry of Finance and Commerce (MFC) also participates in tariff approval. B. Existing Power Facilities 3.4 The existing supply system in Mali comprises of an interconnected power system with a capacity of about 92 MW and 10 isolated centers totaling 13 MW. Detailed characteristics of existing facilities are provided in Annex 1. The Selingue hydroelectric plant is Mali's largest plant and the principal source of electric energy. It has an installed capacity of 44 MW and an average potential output of about 180 GWh. EDM also operates two other plants in Bamako, the Sotuba hydroelectric plant with an installed capacity of 5.4 MW and an average annual output of 39 GWh, and the Dar Salam diesel plant with an installed capacity of 20 MW. The Balingue diesel plant has been completed in 1997 with an installed capacity of 23 MW (in units of 1 to 2.25 MW). The isolated centers are supplied by diesel units varying in capacity from 35 kVA to 1375 kVA, except for the 500 kW Felou hydroelectric plant which meets part of the demand of the town of Kayes. Mali's principal transmission grid interconnected system comprises 350 km of 150 kV lines (130 km from Selingu6 to Bamako, 220 km from Bamako to Segou), 127 km of 66 kV lines (Selingud to Kalano) and 75 km of 30 kV lines forming a loop around Bamako and supplying the town of Koulikoro. The 150 kV and 66 kV systems are reasonably well maintained. The distribution system (15 kV and low voltage lines and substations) in Bamako as well as in the isolated centers is
 7 being rehabilitated and expanded, so that reliability of service will be improved, high energy losses (21%) reduced and access to power expanded. C. Access to Power Service and Consumption 3.5 In 1995, EDM had about 66,200 customers of which about 80% were served by the Bamako system. About 50,000 customers were classified as domestic and about 7% of the Malian population had access to electricity. Even in Bamako, with about 51,000 customers, the rate of electrification is only about 40%. From 1987 to 1995 EDM's electricity sales grew from 135 GWh to 216 GWh, an average annual increase of 6% compared to the rate of about 13% from 1981 to 1987, mainly due to supply limitations (generation capacity and distribution network expansion). Demand studies demonstrate that there is a considerable potential for increased electricity use. To address this supply constraint and improve efficiency of the system, EDM has designed a least-cost development program for the Mali power system, that includes the following: (a) completion of the Selingue Rehabilitation project (Cr. 2850-ML) and rehabilitation and extension of distribution network in Bamako and isolated centers, now being undertaken and financed by the Power II project (Cr.1998-ML); (b) completion of the rehabilitation program and extension of generation systems in isolated systems also underway and funded by CFD and KfW; (c) reinforcement of the thermal capacity by construction of the Balingue plant; and (d) in the medium/long-term (2000/2001), development of the Manantali power development facilities and expansion of the transmission system (Manantali-Bamako; Segou-Sikasso-Koutiala- Bougouni) and possibly the interconnection with the Cote d'Ivoire transmission system.  17 SENEGAL (SENELEC) A. Power Sector Organization 3.32 Until December 1971, electricity supply was in the hands of private companies operating under concessions granted by the Government. In January 1972, the Government terminated the concessions of the most important private company and transferred its functions to the public sector. It was, however, only in 1983 that SENELEC in its present form was created to be responsible for the generation, transmission and distribution of electricity in all of Senegal. Unlike its counterparts in Mali and Mauritania, SENELEC is not involved in supplying water and sewerage services. SENELEC is governed by a Board composed mainly of public sector officials, and management is delegated to a Director General. SENELEC has a large number of employees (2,230), of which about 12% are classified as professionals, all Senegalese nationals. 3.33 The number of connections per employee is about 137. The total number of staff has been slightly reduced in the past five years, but it remains high for a company of this size. Nevertheless, many professional posts are still unfilled. Training is the responsibility of a department attached to the Directorate of Human Resources. 3.34 Sector regulation, policy and coordination are ensured by the Ministry of Energy, Mines and Industry (MEMI). The Ministry of Economy, Finance and Planning (MEFP) also participates in tariff approval. B. Existing Power Facilities 3.35 The existing supply system in Senegal comprises of an interconnected power system with a capacity of about 280 MW, and some 24 isolated centers totaling 50 MW, including Saint- Louis (11 MW), Kahone (14 MW), Boutoute (10 MW), and Tambacounda (5 MW). The largest plant is located in the outskirts of the capital of Dakar (Cap des Biches) with a capacity of 188 MW. All of the plants are thermal-based, and the annual consumption of petroleum products amount to 300,000 tons. SENELEC also purchases excess energy (4 GWh in 1994), from independent producers of electricity who have an installed capacity of around 90 MW. Senegal's principal transmission grid comprises of 60 km of 220 kV, 295 km of 90 kV and 2,000 km of 30 kV lines. It has in addition 650 km of 6.6 kV and 2,500 km of low voltage lines. A BOOT contract is in under negotiation, by which the utility would purchase 300 GWh per year on a take-or-pay basis, with an additional 50 GWh purchased if needed. The 50 MW plant is expected to begin operations in two steps: a 35 MW gas turbine in January 1998 and a 15 MW combined cycle unit in January 1999. C. Access to Power Service and Consumption 3.36 In 1995, SENELEC had more than 280,000 customers, of which 3 industrial consumers (TAIBA, SOCOCIM, ICS) accounted for 20% of the energy sold. Of this total, 170,000 customers are in the Dakar area and the remainder (110,000) in the interior. The rate of electrification is about 25% (50% in the urban centers and 5% in the rural areas).

After a first refusal to certify 1994 accounts, SENELEC and the auditor worked together at the beginning of 1996 in order to address problems identified and carry out all necessary corrections. From 1991 to 1995, energy sales grew at an average annual rate of 5.1% and reached 900 GWh by 1995. This improvement was due to a substantial increase in domestic consumption over the whole period and a sharp rise in industrial demand after the 1994 devaluation. BANK GROUP STRATEGY AND RATIONALE FOR INVOLVEMENT 4.1 One of the main CAS objectives in all three countries] is to achieve sustained broad-based growth by among other things, the promotion of the private sector and the development of infrastructure. Another CAS objective is addressing environmental issues. The project would contribute to achieving these objectives by providing a reliable supply of electric power at lower cost, contributing to increasing the access to electricity of the population in the Senegal river valley and to improving the efficiency of the electric power sectors in the three countries, and helping tackle environmental and health issues related to the existing dam of Manantali, and the construction of the power plant and transmission lines. The project grid will interconnect the major production system of the three countries and make possible exchanges of electricity between the three utilities, and will allow in the long-term interconnection of the three countries with the regional power transmission grid in Western Africa. 4.2 The Bank's involvement in developing the Senegal River Basin dates back to the 1960's. In 1979, it disagreed with OMVS on the rationale for and potential impact of the construction of the Diama and Manantali's dams and withdrew its support to OMVS. Ten years later in 1989, the donors and the three Governments invited the Bank to participate in the financing of the power component and the irrigation schemes in the Senegal valley. This was largely because the OMVS program directly affected policies and strategies in agriculture, health, environment, power and transportation sectors which are vital to economies of the countries concerned and in which the Bank was involved. These complex issues required coordination between three countries under structural adjustment and the three national utilities that already receive Bank support. 4.3 The largest contribution of the Bank (which is providing only about 9% of the financing of the project), has been in ensuring the preparation of a viable project, with the most economic and technically sound design (in particular, concerning the route and design of the Western transmission line), and adequate arrangements for economic management of the Manantali reservoir (through the reservoir management optimization study) and mitigation of environment and health impacts. The project has been determined as the least-cost option for the expansion of the interconnected systems of Mali, Mauritania and Senegal, through the comparison of an all-thermal scenario with a mixed hydro/thermal scenario. Although, prospects for private financing have been reviewed and found not viable, the Bank was instrumental in OMVS decision to subcontract project operations to a private operator under a 15- year concession contract and future generation projects that could be connected to the project transmission grid are likely to attract private financing. 1 Mali CAS: January, 1995 (13746-ML); Mauritania CAS: March, 1994 (6156-MR); Senegal CAS: February, 1995 (13909-SN).
 23 4.4 The Bank supports a coordinated and integrated approach to issues related to the development of the Senegal River Valley. It aims at improving water resource management, rehabilitating and expanding irrigation facilities, improving water supply, reducing the prevalence of endemic diseases and mitigating environment impacts of projects. To that effect, several projects are under preparation in the three countries in coordination with other donors and development agencies, including health sector projects in the three countries, endemic disease control in Senegal, integrated valley development in Mauritania, and water supply development projects in Mauritania and Senegal. . 4.5 Bank's involvement in the power sectors of the three countries aims at assisting authorities reduce the cost of electricity supply and meet reasonable growth in demand while, at the same time, reducing the burden imposed by the sector on Government budgets. Projects are being implemented in Mali [Power II Project (Cr.1998-ML) and the Selingue Rehabilitation Project (Cr.2850-ML)] and are under preparation in Mauritania and Senegal. The Bank's role is consistent with the Bank policy in the power sector (World Bank Policy Papers, the World Bank's Role in the Electric Power Sector, 1993 and Rural Energy and Development, 1996), and is essentially catalytic. These aims would be pursued by a strategy of: (a) improved sector efficiency, by way of strengthening existing power entities, importation of services, commercialization, private sector participation and transparent regulation; (b) the development of indigenous hydro-resources; (c) the promotion of regional interconnection of power and energy; (d) efficiency measures, including economic pricing of electricity; (e) the promotion of rural electrification through decentralization schemes and private involvement; and (f) the reduction of financial burden on public finances in the three countries.

Background 5.1 The Manantali dam, commissioned in 1988, is located on the Bafing River, a tributary of the Senegal river some 1,200 km upstream from the mouth of the river at Saint-Louis. Its construction was financed by Arab donors, IDB, Italy, ADB, CFD, KfW, ACDI and the European Union for about US$500 million. The structure consists of a 1,460 meter long rock-filled dike, flanking a central concrete structure 493 meters long and 65 meters high . The spillway crest is at 208 meters above sea level and the average hydrostatic head on the turbines will be 40 meters. The altitude at the top of the concrete structure is 212 meters above sea level. The reservoir created by the dam has a shoreline of about 150 km. The volume of water retained at elevation 208 meters is 11.3 billion m3, with a lake 2 surface of 477 km . At the minimum operating level of the lake of 187 meters, the volume of stored water is reduced to 3.4 billion m3 with a surface of 275 km2. B. Project Objectives 5.2 The project's main objectives are to: (a) reduce the long-term cost of electricity supply to the three countries; (b) contribute to meeting debt service associated with the building of the Manantali dam; (c) contribute to increasing the efficiency and reliability of power systems in the three countries; (d) establish an effective organization to construct and operate the project facilities and to mitigate environment and health impacts of the project and the Manantali dam; (e) promote competitive private sector participation in project exploitation as well as in financing of future generation projects in the valley; and (f) support the traditional agricultural sector downstream through the rational management of the Manantali reservoir. By tying with the national power systems of OMVS three member states, the power supply from Manantali would also encourage cooperation and coordination between these member countries and allow electricity exchanges between the power utilities. The project transmission grid could also be interconnected at a later stage to the Western African System. C. There was a similar debate with regards to the design of the transmission line, as to whether it should be a single-circuit or double-circuit line. It was finally agreed to opt for the single circuit design, which was confirmed to be technically feasible and reduced project costs by more than US$80 million. For example in 1991, revenues from water-users fees was projected at 172 million FCFA, but actual receipts amounted to only 16 million FCFA. Moreover, about 55% of the expenditures are on personnel and not enough is spent on maintenance of the dam and other structures. Approval and payment procedures are cumbersome for the departments in charge of dam maintenance (particularly for unscheduled maintenance), which budget is chiefly affected by recurrent cash flow difficulties of the organization. As currently structured, OMVS is not a financially autonomous organization and it has a budgetary type of accounting system. 6.7 As a condition for proceeding with the proposed project, a major change in the institutional and organizational setup has been agreed to with OMVS and the three countries. The major objectives of the new institutional framework was (a) to clearly define responsibilities, separating the regulatory and management functions; (b) to provide financial and managerial autonomy of the entity charged of project construction; and (c) to allow for efficient operation and management of the facilities already built and to be built under the proposed project Under the new arrangements, the following was agreed: (a) that the Member-States (Mali, Mauritania, and Senegal), would keep ownership of project assets and facilities and be responsible for debt service on the Manantali and Diama dams; (b) that the High Commission of OMVS (Haut-Commissariat) would be restructured and its responsibilities limited to coordination, regulation and policy matters relating to water management, environment and health impact mitigation and monitoring, etc.; (c) that a new asset holding company, the Societe de Gestion de l'Energie de Manantali (SOGEM), would be created which will be delegated the right to use the power facilities and be responsible for the renewal of the hydropower generation facilities as well as transmission lines;
 39 (d) that a private, professional company, the Societe d'Exploitation de Manantali (SEM), would be recruited and be responsible for operating and managing the power facilities, under a 15-year concession contract, renewable at the end of the period; and (e) that a separate agency be created, under OMVS supervision, to be responsible for managing and operating the Diama dam and related water supply facilities. 6.8 In the future, the Member-States will continue to remain undivided owners of the dams, the dikes and facilities to be built under the proposed project. The Governments will also give in concession to SOGEM the Manantali dam and related equipment. However, SOGEM will be responsible for only 43.8% of the debt service incurred in the construction of the Manantali damn, with the other 56.2% attributed to other activities including irrigation and navigation. Energy generated at Manantali will begin to be dispatched to the three national power utilities (EDM, SONELEC and SENELEC) following the share in the project which is as follows: Mali 52%, Mauritania 15%, and Senegal 33%. However, actual repartition and dispatching will vary on a daily basis depending on the demand and costs of each utility. 6.9 Financial arrangements. SOGEM will be responsible for the renewal of major equipment, and will make appropriate provisions for this. In its agreement with the private operator (SEM), SOGEM will require SEM not only to operate and maintain the power facilities and the dam, according to specified performance indicators, but also to carry out and finance all repairs and replacement of equipment within the timeframe of its contract. Within this framework, the financial flows would be as follows: (a) SEM will bill the national utilities in accordance with the energy sold to each utility and agreed upon tariffs; (b) SEM passes on the revenues to SOGEM, minus its fees and any other contractual expense; (c) with revenues received, SOGEM will: (i) service the project debt on behalf of the Member-States and for the loans it contracts directly; (ii) pay its operating expenses; (iii)constitute adequate provisions for addressing hydrology-related financial risks and for renewal of major equipment; (iv) pay a fee to the Member-States (as per tariff agreement) to reimburse part of the advances made by the States for dam construction and project expenses; (d) any funds remaining over and above those used by SEM and SOGEM will be shared equally by the three States; and (e) The States will continue to finance directly the operations of OMVS. B. SOGEM's Financial Analysis 6.10 Power tariffs to be charged under the project have already been agreed to and are based on numerous studies and the result of difficult negotiations. The main objectives of the tariff structure are: (a) to achieve SOGEM's financial equilibrium, after debt service and the cost of SEM's contract for operation and maintenance; (b) to ensure that the tariff level will be acceptable to the three utilities; and (c) to guarantee sufficient revenues to the Member States, reimbursing them for part of past investments and advances.

The main financial risks borne by the project result from: (a) the evolution of the revenues required from SOGEM; (b) the uncertainty of Manantali energy output, resulting from hydrology; (c) the currency convertibility risk ; and (d) the risk of non-payment of electricity bills by the national power utilities. 6.41 Flexibility of revenues. In Scenario A, SOGEM can easily honor both the debt service of the proposed project as well as the part of the debt service on the dam that refers to the energy component. The redevance (which represents the debt service on the dam) decreases throughout the period, as well as the debt service of the proposed project after 2007. Furthermore, the amount of SOGEM's total applications varies significantly from one specific year to another, as a result of the normal evolution of the debt service on the many different loans involved in the project. Thus, at the beginning of project operations, it will be necessary to postpone in part the provision of the renewal fund and the payment of the dam debt service, so as to allow a smoother evolution of the average level of tariff. The reimbursement of the Member States advances (the part of 1982 to 2001 annuities of the debt service on the dam, that will be transferred to SOGEM), as well as the redevance if necessary, would be partially or completely postponed in case of low energy output. 6.42 Allocating hydrology risk. As the annual output of Manantali may vary significantly with hydrological parameters, there is a need for regulation mechanisms to reduce the impact of the hydrology risk and to optimize the allocation of the remaining part of the risk. Indeed, a stable tariff level, whatever the output, would lead in bad hydrology years to sharp cash shortfalls for SOGEM, whereas giving the priority to SOGEM cash flows will result in an erratic evolution of the tariff level. In order to avoid either problems, the hydrology risk can be greatly reduced by creating a special hydrology fund, which would be provisioned during the best years and used as complementary resource in the driest years. The provisions for fund is considered as a priority as soon as operations begin. In fact, as debt service on the project remains at a low level until 2005, an acceptable level of tariff will generate cash surpluses that could be easily transferred to the hydrology fund. 6.43 But the proposed fund will not fully address the hydrology risk. Therefore, it is necessary to envisage allocating the remaining risk between the project participants. It seems difficult to allocate the risks to the private operator (SEM), which will be mostly concerned with operations and maintenance expenditures for which there is no possible postponement. Secondly, SOGEM can only bear the risk through the hydrology fund. Consequently, the remaining risk can only be borne by the national utilities and the Member States. The forner would assume part of the risk through a tariff formula that allows
 48 for increases if hydrology is insufficient. The members States will have to bear the remaining part through the variable rate of payment of both redevance and past debt service on the dam. 6.44 Currency convertibility and exchange rate risk. During credit negotiations, it was agreed that the exchange rate risk will be borne by SOGEM (para 8.1). The company assumes the debt service, and most loans are contracted in hard currencies. Though operation and maintenance costs are SEM's responsibility, the management contract should include a revision formula based on SEM real costs structure, which will finally transfer the risk to SOGEM. However, a significant and durable depreciation of the CFAF is not likely, as inflation is already low in all three countries. Moreover, if this depreciation should occur, it would be perceptible on thermal generation costs as well, and an eventual adjustment of the tariff level would not compromise the sale of Manantali energy. Currency convertibility issues are only related to payments to be made to SEM in Ougiyas, which however would concern a very limited part of sales (less than 10%) and would be repaid in part by SOGEM to the government of Mauritania for debt service. During credit negotiations, it was agreed that payment of electricity purchased by the utilities will be made in the currency of their respective country, with satisfactory dispositions to be established concerning the conversion of Ougiyas and the bearing of corresponding transaction costs by SOGEM (para 8. 1). 6.45 Mitigating the risk of non-payment. Because of the chronically weak financial situation of all three utilities, it is necessary to address the risk of non-payment of Manantali's electricity bills. Even though sector reforms have recently been implemented or are planned during the period of construction, the risk that one (or more) utility would face sharp cash shortfalls cannot be ruled out.  51 7. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION AND RISKS A. Project Justification 7.1 The electricity supply systems of the three OMVS states are predominantly thermal; only Mali has about 50 MW of hydro generation capacity, while the other two countries have none. Mali also suffers from the handicap of its landlocked location and the poor transport infrastructure to bring fuel from the Atlantic ports of its neighboring countries, which adds over US$100/ton to the cost of fuel. All three power systems are small in size, with a total combined installed capacity of less than 400 MW and do not benefit from economies of scale in power generation. Hence electricity is a high-cost product in the three countries, even at current (low) world oil prices. 7.2 Yet the regulation of the Senegal River in the 1980s, by the construction of two dams, Diama near the mouth of the river, and Manantali, about 1,200 km upstream, has given rise to an opportunity to tap the river's hydroelectric potential. The creation of a reservoir at Manantali with a storage capacity of 11.3 billion cu. m offers the potential of generating 200 MW of power, equivalent to about half of the present combined generating capacity in the three OMVS countries. In economic terms, the existence of the dam and reservoir are unused physical assets which give a hydroelectric generation project an overwhelming advantage over any thermal alternative. 7.3 However, Manantali is in a remote location far from the main electricity markets of Dakar (1,100 km) and Bamako (300 km), and its development for power requires lengthy transmission lines in addition to the power plant. Sluggish economic growth over the 1980s, with a consequent impact on power demand, falling real oil prices and difficulties in reaching agreement on the scope and phasing of the energy project all contributed to the delay in proceeding with it. B. Demand Forecast 7.4 Demand for electricity is growing in all three countries, but at differing rates. Over the past five years, it has increased at an annual average rate of 7.2% in Mali, 7.8% in Mauritania, and 5.1% in Senegal. Details of the demand forecasts are contained in Annex 1 (Table 1.3). These are considered to be realistic in the light of historical trends and projected GDP growth. Mali already suffers from acute power shortages in the dry season and urgently requires new generation capacity. Load shedding amounting to almost 50% of peak demand took place during the two months preceding the 1996 rainy season. Due to the delay in proceeding with the proposed project, Mali is investing in about 20 MW of high-cost, new thermal plant to meet dry season demand during the Manantali construction period. Existing capacity is sufficient to meet peak demand in the other two states (Senegal and Mauritania) till the end of the decade, but they too will face shortages if new plants are not brought on stream within the next five years. However, much of the hydro output from Manantali will meet base-load demand,
 52 enabling a significant reduction in the use of high-cost thermal plants. This renders the proposed project largely immune from fluctuations in the level of total demand. C. Least-cost analysis for system expansion 7.5 The alternative supply solution for each country would have been to proceed independently with increments to their thermal plants. Integrated system planning studies have demonstrated that the least- cost solution is to develop Manantali to meet their combined power needs as estimated by the load forecasts for the three states. OMVS' consultants compared an all-thermal, system expansion scenario with a mixed hydro/thermal scenario in which the three power systems would be interconnected. Details are given in Annex 9. The equalizing discount rate was about 22%, demonstrating the significant cost savings arising from the development of Manantali. These savings arise from (a) deferral of thermal investments, (b) economies in fuel consumption and maintenance costs, and (c) opportunities for exchanges of power between the three utilities to minimize overall system costs, by maximizing use of the lowest cost generation plant, regardless of its location. D. Benefits 7.6 The main project benefits consist of the production of electricity, which has been estimated at an annual average of 804 GWh, based on 1950-94 hydrological data. Given the high variability in rainfall, the annual output from the project is subject to a considerable degree of uncertainty. The use of a shorter hydrological time series (1970-94), has a very significant impact on the estimated energy output from Manantali, which drops to 547 GWh, because of the succession of very dry years in the late 1970s/early 1980s. The base case economic analysis of the project has been based on the average output of the 1950- 94 hydrological series, but this has been subjected to a full risk analysis (Annex 9), in the light of the high variability of rainfall. 7.7 The average net electricity output of the project has been conservatively valued at the current weighted average high voltage tariff of the three companies (CFAF 63/US$0.12 per kWh). This is considered to be the minimum economic value of the plant output. Present, low voltage tariffs are significantly higher (CFAF 82/US$0.16 per kWh), and consumer willingness-to-pay for reliable power supply is deemed to be significantly higher than the value used to estimate the benefits of the project. 7.8 Simulations carried out by OMVS' consultants show that the transmission lines to be built to bring power from Manantali to the three capital cities will also be used to reverse the direction of power flows when justified by fuel savings. For example, the heavy fuel oil units in Nouakchott produce electricity at a lower cost than some of the units in Dakar and thus power from Nouakchott would flow to Senegal at certain times. Similarly, there are expected to be periods when power would flow eastwards from Dakar to Mali. The interconnection will thus allow system-wide fuel savings by optimizing the use of generation plant. Such benefits have not been included in the estimate of the project's internal rate of return. E. Allocation of water between irrigation, artificial flooding and energy 7.9 Both of the estimates of energy output from Manantali (para 7.6) take into account the requirement to release sufficient water from the reservoir to produce an artificial flood of about 5.5 billion m3 in all but driest years. A flood of this size would permit the cultivation of sorghum on at least 50,000 ha. of flood plain by traditional methods, as well as a number of environment benefits which are outlined in Annex 10. However, such a support to the natural flood is not possible during the driest years
 53 (I out of 7 in average). Under the 1950-94 hydrological series, the average energy output from Manantali would be about 7% higher without the constraint to provide an artificial flood, but there would then be an unacceptable reduction in the frequency of occurrence of the flood. The proposed reservoir management strategy is thus a compromise that strikes a good balance between these competing uses for the water. Providing a larger flood than 5.5 billion cu. m would further reduce the electricity output while only marginally increasing the area actually cultivated. On the other hand, reducing or eliminating the flood entirely to maximize electricity output would be too costly for a multitude of economic, social, political and environmental reasons, as explained in Annex IO. 7.10 The agreed reservoir management strategy for the proposed project is thus a compromise between energy and flood-recession agriculture. At present, the water requirements for pumped irrigation are not a constraint for energy production. An artificial flood can also be produced in years of average rainfall while still holding back sufficient water in the reservoir to meet irrigation needs and generate about 800 GWh of electricity. As the area of irrigated land increases, the higher dry season flow needed for agriculture can still be passed through the turbines to first generate power. Nevertheless, there is a risk that in the long term, once the area under irrigation largely exceeds 100,000 ha., the release of water for an artificial flood may come into conflict with both irrigation and power in dry years. However, this may take another 20 years as the current pace of development is only about 2000 ha. per year in gross terms. In addition, improved returns to irrigated agriculture would help to reduce dependence on flood-recession cultivation and thus diminish the need for an artificial flood. In the past, prior to the construction of the dams, rural populations were adapted to the risk of occasional dry years when no flood-recession cultivation was possible. The construction of the dans allows improved timing of flood water releases and interannual water storage, thereby enabling more frequent 'artificial' floods than would occur if the river had remained unregulated. However, in the driest years it would be impossible to create a flood because releases from Manantali only represent about half the flows needed for the Senegal to overflow its banks. F. Economic Rate of Return 7.11 The base case internal rate of return (IRR) on the project was estimated to be 16%. Details of the calculations are contained in Annex 9. The investment already made in the dam was excluded from the analysis. However, the loss in agricultural output arising from a reduction in the average area of flood-recession cultivation was considered as a cost and included in the analysis. Additional benefits to the energy sector from interconnection, such as fuel savings from bilateral energy trading were excluded. G. Sensitivity Analysis 7.12 The IRR falls to 11% if the annual average gross energy output over the 1970-94 period is used (547 GWh). The impact of a 10% cost over-run is to lower the base-case IRR to 14%. However the risks of such an overrun are low, as bids have already been received for project components that account for about half of project costs. The effect of a one-year delay in completing the project is a reduction in the base case IRR to 15%. The risk of such an occurrence is considered low because the construction of a transmission line over flat terrain does not present any particular technical difficulties and the process of land and rights-of-way acquisition has already begun. 7.13 The IRR is not sensitive to changes in the final demand for electricity because the plant would mainly serve for base load, thereby allowing the national power companies to reduce the operations of
 54 higher-cost thermal plant. The impact of lower than expected demand growth would therefore only be felt in the utilization rate of thermal plant. H. Probabilistic risk analysis 7.14 A risk analysis was carried out to assess the impact on the project's IRR of the uncertainty in key variables, particularly hydrology and energy output, project costs, construction time and the loss of traditional agricultural output from reduced flood-plain cultivation. A spreadsheet based software (Crystal Ball) was used to that effect. The risk analysis showed that the base case IRR varies from 11.6% to 17.2% with an 90% probability of being more than 13.1%. In the low-hydrology variant, the IRR ranges between 6.3% and 12.4% and has a 90% probability of being above 8.2%. Details are contained in Annex 9. I. The multi-purpose nature of the Manantali project means that its maximum potential energy output is constrained by the need to take into account other uses for the water stored in the reservoir. In the long term, irrigation will require a constant flow in the dry season of at least 100 cubic meters per second (cusecs) at Bakel, while the future needs of shipping3 would raise this to 200 cusecs. These flows would not conflict with power generation, as the water would first pass through the turbines. In theory; it would therefore be possible to operate the reservoir so as to maximize electricity production. On the other hand, the OMVS member states have concluded that there are strong economic, social, political and environmental reasons (paras. 2-6) to perpetuate the traditional flooding of the flat plain along the Senegal river between Bakel and Dagana. This gives rise to an obligation to release sufficient water from the Manantali reservoir to create an 'artificial' flood4 at the end of the rainy season. The volumes required for the flood mean that some water may be spilled without being used for power generation, which in turn imposes a cost in terms of foregone energy generation in the ensuing dry season. Rationale for an artificial flood 2. The flood has numerous beneficial features5 which justify perpetuating it artificially at least for another twenty years, the time required for it to be progressively replaced by irrigated agriculture. The main benefits are environmental and agricultural. The latter are easy to quantify as the flood permits the cultivation of sorghum on the flood plain. It is a significant source of complementary income (para. 3) and food security for over one hundred thousand households in the Senegal Valley. Flood-recession agriculture is an economic activity that is unlikely to be abandoned voluntarily by peasants, because it requires no cash inputs and much less labor than irrigated agriculture and is almost risk-free. Socio-anthropological research shows that the majority of the population of the Senegal Valley relies on three sources of income: irrigated agriculture, recession cultivation and external remittances. doc.abstracts: The Regional Hydropower Development Project's main objectives are to: (i) reduce the long-term cost of electricity supply to the 3 countries; (ii) contribute to meeting debt service associated with the building of the Manantali dam; (iii) contribute to increasing the efficiency and reliability of power systems; (iv) establish an effective organization to construct and operate the project facilities and to mitigate environment and health impacts of the projects and the Manantali dam; (v) promote competitive private sector participation; and (vi) support the traditional agricultural sector downstream through the rational management of the Manantali reservoir. The project's components are as follows: 1) power station including civil works, electromechanical equipment, step-up substation, and reinforcement works; 2) transmission system comprising transmission lines and a dispatching center; 3) construction supervision; 4) institutional strengthening including studies, training, procurement of equipment and other support; and 5) Project Preparation Facility Advance refinancing.
